Does your son play infield/outfield? 

Are they between the age 9-16?

If so, then this clinic is for them!

Myself and current Seton Hall coach Ryan Ramiz are co-hosting an elite fielding and hitting clinic on Friday June 21st. We only have a limited number of spots available, so sign-up quickly! (Info provide below)

I'm a former pitcher with the Baltimore Orioles organization, but before that I was a 2x All-Conference Shortstop/Third base man, that set a single season RBI record for Lenoir-Rhyne University.

Ryan Ramiz is a 2x All-Big East outfielder that was drafted in the 2018 MLB draft by the Miami Marlins and loanDepot park.

Together we look forward to talking all things Hitting, Fielding, & Recruiting.

If you're interested in signing up your son, you can either email "Info@arenasportsnj.com" or reach out to me separately.

I look forward to working with your son and sharing all the information I wish I had when I was younger!

As the skin market continues to only grow over the past decade, especially with the recent rumors of a "Source 2" or Counterstrike 2 coming, it continues to blow people's minds as huge gaming collectors continue to drop such large amounts on in-game skins and items

For those unaware of CS, the rarity of the skin itself is one thing, then there is also a float for the skin and even potential patterns in the skin. The lower the float typically the better the skin. Then you have the general wear and tear from "battle scarred" to "factory new". And then you can apply stickers to your weapon like this one, with some stickers being worth up to $60,000 just by themselves...

The market is truly insane and I have been trying to get in touch with traders to interview about it.

#youtube #creatoreconomy #branding #business","likeCount":327,"commentCount":43,"repostCount":1,"postDate":"2yr","action":"James S. likes this","author":"Reed Duchscher","authorUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/reedjd","profileUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/sales/lead/ACwAACqnlUkBE-T7qxgUAGMa1Mb757p69QUEs34,NAME_SEARCH,3aMp","timestamp":"2025-11-07T14:09:35.982Z","postTimestamp":"2023-01-20T19:07:21.536Z"},{"postUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7022246114145792000","imgUrl":"","postContent":"‚Äú99% of the best founders I have worked with, played video games to supremely high levels in their childhood.‚Äù - Harry Stebbings Founder @ 20VC

5 Ways Playing Video Games Helps Train Future Entrepreneurs

1) Agency mindset
What distinguishes a video game from all other media (TV, film, books) is that games are interactive - meaning the player is no longer watching the action, she is taking the action.   YOU are the protagonist.  You make choices that matter.  You develop a bias for action.

2) Growth mindset 
Games are challenging and require persistence and resilience to complete levels and/or conquer opponents.   Games provide a safe environment to fail over and over again as you master each challenge.  Thus you learn that failure is a core part of the learning process toward skill improvement & goal accomplishment. 

3) Teamwork
While you are the protagonist, you always go farther with others. These days the most popular games are played online & require cooperation and communication across a group of players to accomplish the goal.

4) Strategic Thinking
Games require you to decide when and how to allocate limited resources (be that energy, gold, skill points, power-ups & potions, etc) toward your end goal.  You must think critically about the best course of action and often make those challenging decisions very quickly and with imperfect information.

5) Gateway to Computer Programming/STEAM/IT skills
For so many founders gaming was the gateway to learning computer programming, digital art, user-interface design, and/or other technical and IT skills that benefit founders of startup companies. 

Making that jump from consuming a game to creating an in-game asset is often the first step toward creating at an even greater scale.

I‚Äôve always struggled with having a sense of belonging - and a part of me assumed getting my dream job against all odds would fix that.

Not a lot of people can switch to a brand-new and highly competitive industry, without a referral, after getting rejected from about 30 jobs in a row. So that has to mean I did a great job selling myself, all the certifications I achieved paid off, and all the interview practice I got during my job search must have helped right? 

‚Ä¶Right? 

To my disappointment,  that sense of ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt deserve to be here‚Äù didn‚Äôt go away on my first day. Or my first week. Or my first month. 

Finding people to relate to was very difficult. Even though many of my coworkers were also new to gaming, they came from other top companies like Google, or Amazon, or Marvel. I came from a dinky company of 100 people and my side hustle was trading social media tips for haircuts from salon owners on Groupon. 

But, having a lot to prove is something that has made me excel. I have continued to use these feelings as a motivator to seize every opportunity possible and keep growing. 

Learning and accepting that people value my input and actively seek my opinion has been a very difficult journey. I‚Äôm very lucky to be working in a place where so many people along the way have really helped me believe it.

Why? Because every day she goes to bat for every candidate and person out there who feels unseen, who feels unsupported, who feels like they can't do it. She greets them with love and kindness and gives them practical tips and encouragement on how they can make their life and career dreams happen

This thread is extremely important and I applaud Arin's bravery in sharing it. Much of the contents within it are disgusting

IF YOU EVER MAKE SUCH INSULTING AND DISTRESSING COMMENTS ABOUT ARIN, ANY WOMAN, OR ANY PERSON OF ANY IDENTITY IN A WORKPLACE, YOU ARE INSULTING ME, MY MOTHER, MY GRANDMOTHER, AND MY WHOLE FAMILY TOO

I always emphasize positivity and the best in our industry. However, as I say often, I never pretend, for a single day, that there aren't miles left to walk in many areas to become the industry I know it can be

Arin, I am saddened, but, unfortunately, not surprised

The tired tropes featured in your post are those many of us see around us each day:

*Shaming someone because of their appearance
*Jealously towards a successful person who may not fit a specific profile people think they are "supposed to"
*Straight-up misogynies and racism

But there are also more subtle ones that I have experienced myself:

*People judging you as weak because you either are a shy or quiet person or, like me, maybe don't "sound" traditional. Believe it or not I have been ridiculed for having a relatively high voice. Or people judging you for not meeting some type of aggressive alpha profile

*People not taking you seriously because you aren't a career games professional. I have often observed the industry does a poor job of integrating those who enter it particularly later in career, as there is a bias towards tenure, as well as assumptions around ability to perform without that tenure (the "we have always done it this way, with these types of people, with these types of skills" syndrome)

*People believing that things like social media posts, even if done in your own free time, do not convey "seriousness," even if what you are doing is informative and helpful and is significantly brand-boosting for your underlying organization

*Those who denigrate diversity and inclusion topics and discussions as a "waste of time" or "distraction," like the other day when I received toxicity from trolls for discussing Blizzard embracing diverse body types in games

It is a sad and dark day when someone who has devoted their life and every moment to helping others is treated in such a pitiful way

Chin up Arin. You are doing it all right and, above all else, it is inevitable that if you reach a certain level of visibility and success, which you have, the nut jobs will come out of the woodwork, often just to try to grab a glimmer of brightness for themselves off of an actual, shining star","likeCount":34,"commentCount":7,"repostCount":0,"postDate":"2yr","action":"James S. supports this","author":"Amir Satvat","authorUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/amirsatvat","profileUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/sales/lead/ACwAACqnlUkBE-T7qxgUAGMa1Mb757p69QUEs34,NAME_SEARCH,3aMp","timestamp":"2025-11-07T14:09:57.030Z","postTimestamp":"2022-12-08T12:02:32.121Z"},{"postUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7005542354954723329","imgUrl":"https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/C5622AQEgHiPWkLZ0CA/feedshare-shrink_800/feedshare-shrink_800/0/1670181563864?e=1764201600&v=beta&t=tkvM-RKOj63QOyv7V51om91BuLOh4jhyN8UgXqFnA40","type":"Image","postContent":"I appreciate the emotional honesty of this piece of wood.","likeCount":4364,"commentCount":80,"repostCount":36,"postDate":"2yr","action":"James S. finds this funny","author":"Lex Fridman","authorUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/lexfridman","profileUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/sales/lead/ACwAACqnlUkBE-T7qxgUAGMa1Mb757p69QUEs34,NAME_SEARCH,3aMp","timestamp":"2025-11-07T14:09:57.031Z","postTimestamp":"2022-12-05T14:44:14.104Z"},{"postUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7004591105413443584","imgUrl":"https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/C5622AQFFeR3S5nFfdw/feedshare-shrink_800/feedshare-shrink_800/0/1670022254121?e=1764201600&v=beta&t=yKXUA5qiyDJvlhPIGoM3wcupOkoO_nA1LGXpLlvl87k","type":"Image","postContent":"You don't want to miss the #NFLTNG Playoffs next week!

This weekend's DreamHack BYOC (Bring Your Own Computer or Console) event was the LARGEST-EVER LAN in ATLANTA!

Why would someone disconnect and pack up their perfectly working computer from their house or apartment...

load it up in the car...

travel all the way to Atlanta, a multi-hour trip for many...

deal with the cold weather, parking...

set up the hardware, monitor, cables, peripherals, chair all over again inside a convention center...

play all weekend long...

PAY for that privilege & experience...

expect to see thousands of others doing the same thing...

and have even more people show up than expected?

So why should esports be any different?

In conjunction with BMW Group, we sought to answer that. Through their 25 years of knowledge and experience in 3D scanning and printing within traditional sports, together, we were able to forge the Vision Mouse.

This process involved over 1000 hours of development through 3D scanning each of the player's hands, analyzing their grip styles during gameplay, and interviewing them on material, weight, and design preferences.

Our gear team was then able to utilize these insights to create the first versions of the 3D-printed Vision mice. Then through multiple iterations, alterations, and tweaks, which were then further reviewed and tested at each stage by our League of Legends roster, we settled on the 5 individual designs for each of the players.

Learn more about the Fnatic x BMW Vision Mouse here: https://lnkd.in/eWPksW4J

Stay tuned to our channels to keep up with this project
This is only the beginning of an exciting journey not only for us but for the esports industry as a whole.

Link in the comment to join üòâ","likeCount":1,"commentCount":0,"repostCount":0,"postDate":"3yr","action":"James S. loves this","author":"Esra Demirel","authorUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ezsra","profileUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/sales/lead/ACwAACqnlUkBE-T7qxgUAGMa1Mb757p69QUEs34,NAME_SEARCH,3aMp","timestamp":"2025-11-07T14:10:26.544Z","postTimestamp":"2022-07-11T14:23:24.893Z"},{"postUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6952261626922221569","imgUrl":"https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/C5622AQFnhBJ3VY0M4Q/feedshare-shrink_800/feedshare-shrink_800/0/1657546857095?e=1764201600&v=beta&t=V7kfa0qzS7R0QrWNg1rnXRYrBUjxipbFQYvEMwRZmKA","type":"Image","postContent":"It is one of my favorite times of the year - Famicom week. 39 years ago this Friday Nintendo first released perhaps the most important console in games history in Japan

What an amazing piece of hardware. Before it was modified into its North American counterpart, this beauty had a white and red plastic body, two controllers (one of which had a microphone function for karaoke and other uses, and with a design borrowed from Game & Watch), a red knob to slide games in and out of the pin slot, on/off and reset buttons, a port for accessories, and 3D and handheld microphone addon functionality

The cartridges came in multiple colors and there were no lock-out chips, meaning you could alter and write your own games

Not a bad piece of kit for about $500 today

Oh yah, and its success gave Nintendo the confidence to create its North American cousin, the Nintendo Entertainment System, which saved our video game industry from bankruptcy, which lost 97% of its market capitalization from 1983 to 1985 ($3.2B to $100M)

Consider this my appreciation card to you Famicom, in the form of a big cartridge heart in your native red and white

It's strange, I've never been a huge PC gamer, always preferred my consoles. But the game I've put the most time into has to be WoW. I dedicated 2 years of my life to it when first released and having thought I had managed to quit, the recent release of Classic pulled me right back in!

The game has been played in 244 countries and territories around the world, with over 500 million characters created in-game! It was amazing to play and chat with other gamers across the world and when it came to end game, there was nothing like being part of a strong guild and taking down Ragnaros at the end of Molten Core in a 40 man raid for the first time!

During our Metaverse campaign this month, I am curious to hear what games you guys loved, that immersed you in the world of gaming!

As I begin to moderate and grow more communities, the lessons you provided are extremely valuable in dealing with many challenges that we face. However, these tips aren't just relevant to community moderators and managers, but to anyone that currently works with remote teams. I'd like to share those key lessons below as a reference: 

üíû Build a stronger internal community by leaning on other moderators for support. 

üìÖ Set up a healthy work/life boundary through time blocking and separate accounts for personal and moderating. 

üòñ Focus on controlling your reactions and not your emotions. 

‚è≥ Take a deep breath and reframe your mindset about the situation. 

üì¥ Make going offline, disconnecting, and gratitude a routine.

These amazing tips and more were presented by Meaghan Highwood and Jason Docton. Personally, I love to advocate for more mental health and inclusion resources within the gaming community so in support of #MentalHealthAwarenessMonth, please check out https://youarerad.org/ 

RAD is a nonprofit who's mission is to make mental health care accessible to everyone, everywhere. Thank you for all the amazing work that you do!

NASA‚Äôs Parker Solar Probe has taken its first visible light images of the surface of Venus from space.

Smothered in thick clouds, Venus‚Äô surface is usually shrouded from sight. But in two recent flybys of the planet, Parker used its Wide-Field Imager, or WISPR, to image the entire nightside in wavelengths of the visible spectrum ‚Äì the type of light that the human eye can see ‚Äì and extending into the near-infrared.

The images, combined into a video, reveal a faint glow from the surface that shows distinctive features like continental regions, plains, and plateaus. A luminescent halo of oxygen in the atmosphere can also be seen surrounding the planet.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre thrilled with the science insights Parker Solar Probe has provided thus far,‚Äù said Nicola Fox, division director for the Heliophysics Division at NASA Headquarters. ‚ÄúParker continues to outperform our expectations, and we are excited that these novel observations taken during our gravity assist maneuver can help advance Venus research in unexpected ways.‚Äù

Such images of the planet, often called Earth‚Äôs twin, can help scientists learn more about Venus‚Äô surface geology, what minerals might be present there, and the planet‚Äôs evolution. Given the similarities between the planets, this information can help scientists on the quest to understand why Venus became inhospitable and Earth became an oasis. 

‚ÄúVenus is the third brightest thing in the sky, but until recently we have not had much information on what the surface looked like because our view of it is blocked by a thick atmosphere,‚Äù said Brian Wood, lead author on the new study and physicist at the Naval Research Laboratory in Washington, DC. ‚ÄúNow, we finally are seeing the surface in visible wavelengths for the first time from space.‚Äù

The WISPR images show features on the Venusian surface, such as the continental region Aphrodite Terra, the Tellus Regio plateau, and the Aino Planitia plains. Since higher altitude regions are about 85 degrees Fahrenheit cooler than lower areas, they show up as dark patches amidst the brighter lowlands. These features can also be seen in previous radar images, such as those taken by Magellan.

Beyond looking at surface features, the new WISPR images will help scientists better understand the geology and mineral make-up of Venus. When heated, materials glow at unique wavelengths. By combining the new images with previous ones, scientists now have a wider range of wavelengths to study, which can help identify what minerals are on the surface of the planet. Such techniques have previously been used to study the surface of the Moon. Future missions will continue to expand this range of wavelengths, which will contribute to our understanding of habitable planets.
